entries.title: Ethotechnics
entries.bodyHtml: The discipline of designing sociotechnical systems that reliably uphold moral obligations. It treats moral behavior as engineered capability expressed in policy, interfaces, and operations—so harm can be prevented, stopped, and repaired on a clock with a named owner.
examples: A hospital release board requires consent checks, stop controls, and named repair owners before deploying triage updates.
entries.scope: A. Core concepts. These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.
operationalTests: Documentation maps moral obligations to concrete mechanisms (stoppability, contestability, repair ownership).
Teams can show a shipped feature where moral performance was designed, measured, and iterated.
entries.genealogy: Draws from ethics, safety engineering, and systems design to align governance, product, and operations around observable moral performance.

entries.title: Moral Behavior (of Systems)
entries.bodyHtml: Observable system outcomes that prevent harm, distribute burden fairly, and keep people able to contest and recover. Moral behavior is evaluated via MPIs like time-to-halt, reversibility, and fair burden distribution—not by stated intent. A system does not “behave morally” if MPIs are tracked but do not trigger pause rules, remediation, or resourcing.
examples: A payments platform slows risky recommendations, surfaces a human review queue, and documents reversals when fraud indicators spike.
entries.scope: A. Core concepts. These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.
operationalTests: MPIs are tracked and drive operational thresholds or pause rules.
Post-incident reviews tie outcomes to system controls rather than intent statements.
entries.genealogy: Defines the observable outcomes Ethotechnics expects across governance, design, and operations.

entries.title: Ethical Load Path
entries.bodyHtml: The traceable chain of authority, decisions, and controls that carries moral responsibility through a system. A clear ethical load path names who can stop, reverse, or repair harm at each stage, linking design authority, oversight horizons, and the repair log so handoffs remain accountable.
examples: A transit authority publishes a named escalation map for halting automated dispatch, including after-hours owners.
entries.scope: A. Core concepts. These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.
operationalTests: Each lifecycle stage has a named owner with authority to stop, reverse, or repair, plus backup coverage.
Incident reviews show the escalation path was used without dead ends or orphaned decisions.
entries.genealogy: Adapts engineering load paths to accountability so responsibility stays traceable across handoffs.

entries.title: Ethotechnic Audit
entries.bodyHtml: A structured assessment of a system’s moral capabilities, including stoppability, reversibility, burden distribution, contestability, and accountability. Ethotechnic audits validate evidence, stress-test pathways, and define remediation steps with named owners.
examples: After a harmful rollout, a platform audit verifies stop controls, reversal paths, and repair ownership before relaunch.
entries.scope: A. Core concepts. These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.
operationalTests: Audit evidence includes drills, logs, and user-facing pathways for contesting and repairing harm.
Remediation plans are time-bound, assigned to owners, and re-audited after major changes.
entries.genealogy: Builds on safety and compliance audits while centering harm prevention, repair, and accountability.

entries.title: Conviviality
entries.bodyHtml: The degree to which tools and institutions expand people’s agency, cooperation, and right of refusal instead of enclosing them. Convivial systems keep permission surfaces wide, make opting out safe, and let communities shape the service.
examples: A mutual aid platform lets neighbors pause notifications or change delivery preferences without losing access to support.

operationalTests: People can refuse or change terms without losing core access or being penalized.
Interfaces surface shared control settings instead of only provider defaults.

entries.title: Ethotechnic Maturity
entries.bodyHtml: A developmental scale describing how consistently a system embodies Ethotechnic capabilities across its lifecycle. Early maturity focuses on stopping acute harms; later stages add graceful degradation, contestability, and routine care retrospectives. Mature systems publish SLJs, maintain repair capacity, and review moral performance on a steady cadence.
examples: A rail operator publishes service-level justice metrics, runs quarterly pause drills, and funds dedicated repair staffing.
entries.scope: A. Core concepts. These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.
operationalTests: A maturity level is documented with evidence for each capability and reviewed after major releases.
Maintenance and repair staffing, budgets, and tools are recurring, not ad hoc.

entries.title: Legibility
entries.bodyHtml: How understandable a system’s actions, reasoning, and ownership are to the people affected by it. Legibility complements explainability for accountability and transparent design authority so people can find who decided, why, and how to respond. Legibility is discoverability of who/why/what-next; it does not guarantee the system can be changed.
examples: Residents receive a plain-language notice that names the office, rule, and appeal path behind a zoning decision.
entries.scope: A. Core concepts. These terms define the Ethotechnics discipline itself and set expectations for moral system design.
operationalTests: Decision notices include a plain-language rationale, owner, and next step for contesting.
Affected people can reach the policy basis and escalation path within a single click or call.
entries.genealogy: Moves transparency from disclosure to actionable understanding for the people impacted.

entries.title: Sociotechnical Alignment
entries.bodyHtml: Alignment achieved not just in the model, but across tools, interfaces, incentives, workflows, and organizational structures. Sociotechnical alignment keeps the ethical load path intact under pressure.
examples: Policy, tooling, and incentives all enforce the same stoppability rules.

entries.title: Moral Latency
entries.bodyHtml: The lag between harm occurring and the system detecting or responding to it. Automation can scale impact faster than oversight, so moral latency demands velocity friction and ethical interrupts that shrink response time.
examples: A clinic triage chatbot keeps routing patients while harm reports queue for hours, delaying escalation.
entries.scope: B. Failure modes (why Ethotechnics exists). Common patterns where responsibility dissolves and harm accelerates.
operationalTests: Time-to-detect harm exceeds time-to-scale the impact.
Alerts are not tied to pause, rollback, or escalation controls for moral risk.

entries.title: Accountability Diffusion
entries.bodyHtml: Responsibility spreads across teams, vendors, and incentives until no one can intervene. Accountability diffusion erodes design authority and leaves harm without a decisive owner. If no one can unilaterally stop or reverse the harm, accountability is diffused.
examples: A support ticket bounces between a vendor and a hospital compliance team with no one empowered to pause the rollout.
entries.scope: B. Failure modes (why Ethotechnics exists). Common patterns where responsibility dissolves and harm accelerates.
operationalTests: Escalation maps lack a single owner with authority to stop or repair.
Incident reviews show repeated handoffs without a clear decision point.

entries.title: Extraction
entries.bodyHtml: When a system pulls value—data, attention, labor, or social capital—without returning care, consent, or repair. Extraction hides true costs through externalization and steep burden gradients, hollowing trust.
examples: A data-labeling program offloads unpaid overnight verification to gig workers while the platform reports clean metrics.

operationalTests: Value metrics are tracked without corresponding burden or consent metrics.
Unpaid or unacknowledged labor is required to keep the system functioning.

entries.bodyHtml: Systems that rely on workers or users absorbing fragility through burnout, emotional labor, or unpaid cognitive work—often mislabeled as “resilience.” Ethotechnic practice aims to invert this burden with fair burden distribution.

entries.title: Drift (System Drift)
entries.bodyHtml: The tendency of systems to drift toward harm over time when incentives, data, or constraints shift. Without protective friction and moral performance indicators, drift quietly erodes safeguards and accountability.

entries.title: Externalization
entries.bodyHtml:
Pushing risk, cost, or harm onto other teams, communities, or the future so internal metrics look clean. Externalization appears as pollution, shadow labor, or brittle dependencies outside audits.

Ethotechnics counters it with oversight horizons, MPIs, and transparent repair logs.

entries.title: Brittleness
entries.bodyHtml: When a system fractures under real-world variance—unexpected inputs, refusals, or edge cases—forcing humans to absorb the impact. Brittleness signals missing soft edges, thin graceful degradation, and poor refusal tolerance.
examples: A flight booking bot fails on hyphenated surnames, forcing agents to rebook travelers at the counter.

entries.title: Precision Laundering
entries.bodyHtml: Using detailed metrics or probabilistic scores to disguise inequity as objectivity. Precision laundering hides burden gradients and externalization behind statistical gloss, undermining explainability for accountability and meaningful contestation.

entries.bodyHtml: When rigid policy checklists replace judgment, causing teams to follow rules while harm worsens. Compliance collapse occurs when design authority is weak and contestability is low, leaving no path to pause or repair.

categories.heading: C. Ethotechnic capabilities (what systems must be able to do)
categories.descriptionHtml: Design requirements that keep people safe when systems scale.

entries.title: Stoppability
entries.bodyHtml: A system’s ability to halt harmful processes quickly, safely, and deliberately—without requiring heroism or escalation. Stoppability pairs ethical interrupts with measurable time-to-halt targets.

operationalTests: Each high-risk workflow has documented stop controls, owners, and on-call coverage.

entries.title: Reversibility
entries.bodyHtml:
Critical actions can be undone and people restored to a safe prior state. Damage is not permanent by default, and time-to-restore stays low.

Minimum evidence

  • User-facing artifact.
  • Internal log.
  • Drill / rehearsal.

entries.title: Contestability
entries.bodyHtml: People affected by system decisions can challenge, change, or overturn them—and win. Contestability requires a visible permission surface and a healthy appeal passage rate.
